abstracts.cdata!:
The Federal Water Resources Management
            Project will support the development of water resources
            management capacity at the Federal, State and user levels,
            and the implementation of the necessary infrastructure to
            ensure optimal resource utilization in order to address both
            water supply and demand management issues of ten States in
            the Northeast and the Federal Government (National
            Secretariat of Water Resources - SRH). Improving capacity
            for water quality monitoring and the corresponding
            regulatory framework at the state level would reinforce
            attention to water quality issues in a decentralized manner.
            The implementation of water use charges and rates systems is
            a new concept in the region. The payment by public agency
            providers (e.g. State Water Companies) as well as
            residential and industrial water users of bulk water charges
            to basin agencies and/or SRHs may generate internal
            controversy. In addition, the requirement that State water
            providers and private users (including irrigation users)
            obtain a water right from the relevant Federal or State
            agency for the use of water resources may be controversial.
            Effective participation of water users in the
            decision-making process regarding the implementation of
            hydraulic infrastructure is another controversial aspect
            supported by the project. The project will be based on: (i)
            improvements in the standards of living in the rural sector
            related to improved health and income gains; and (ii)
            increased beneficiary ability to cope with droughts. The
            major negative impact is to assure fair and equitable
            conflict resolution to prevent inequities from occurring and
            obtain strong commitment from the Federal and State
            Governments in this regard. Potential negative impacts of
            the project include expropriation of 50 rural properties,
            resulting in leaseback of 70 families, stoppage of
            productive activities, cultural impacts and risks of
            disintegration of family. The loss of infrastructure linked
            to the Missi dam project consists of 70 houses, a school and
            two cemeteries.
